title: How to Season Potatoes

steps.headline: Use fresh rosemary, thyme, and parsley for an aromatic dish.
steps.description: For rosemary and thyme, strip the leaves from the stems by holding a sprig of the herb in between 2 fingers and running those fingers down the stem—this will quickly pluck the leaves from the stem for you. Finely mince the leaves. For parsley, use the entire herb—stem and leaves. Just chop off the bottom of the stems and discard them, and then finely chop the rest of the parsley. Before cutting fresh herbs, rinse them off and make sure they are completely dry. Wet herbs can turn into mushy herbs when they are chopped.

steps.headline: Add garlic to your potatoes.
steps.description: Use roasted garlic, freshly minced garlic, crushed garlic, or even sprinkle garlic salt or garlic powder onto your potatoes before you cook them. Garlic is very aromatic and can be combined with lots of other herbs and seasonings. When buying garlic, look for bulbs that don’t have mold or green shoots coming off of them. To remove that garlicky smell from your hands, rub a stainless steel object, like a spatula or tongs, while washing your hands with gold water.

steps.headline: Sprinkle garam masala onto cubed potatoes for a warm, spicy dish.
steps.description: Use 2 teaspoons (9.9 mL) of garam masala for 3 medium potatoes. As you learn how much spice you like, you can increase or decrease the amount you put on your potatoes. Garam masala is made of cinnamon, nutmeg, cloves, cardamom, mace, peppercorns, coriander, and cumin. You can buy this spice blend at most grocery stores. Apply the garam masala before baking the potatoes for the most flavor.

steps.headline: Toss your potatoes in plain or flavored extra-virgin olive oil.
steps.description: Place uncooked, cubed potatoes into a large mixing bowl and drizzle them with 2 to 3 tablespoons (30 to 44 mL) of olive oil. Buy flavored extra-virgin olive oil, like garlic, basil, or Tuscan herb, from specialty stores. The olive oil will help the potatoes get crispy when you bake them in the oven or cook them on the stovetop.

steps.headline: Coat the potatoes in a pesto sauce for a fresh, bright dish.
steps.description: Buy a jar of pesto at the store, or make your own pesto to use. Cube 6-7 potatoes, put them into a gallon-size plastic bag, add about ⁄4 cup (180 mL) of pesto, zip the bag closed, and shake it until the potatoes are evenly coated. Then cook the potatoes in the oven at 450 °F (232 °C) for about 25 minutes. For an even more intense flavor, add some parmesan cheese to the potatoes after they’ve cooked.

steps.headline: Sprinkle brown sugar onto sweet potatoes for a sweet treat.
steps.description: Bake whole sweet potatoes in the oven at 400 °F (204 °C) for about 45 minutes. Let them cool down for about 5 minutes, and then use a knife to cut them open lengthwise. Then, sprinkle a little bit of brown sugar onto each side of the potato. For a more delectable potato, add a little butter before sprinkling them with the brown sugar.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 400 °F (204 °C) and cut the potatoes into quarters.
steps.description: Use a clean cutting board and a sharp kitchen knife, and cut each potato into 4 equal quarters. If there are any spuds growing off of your potatoes, simply rub them off and throw them away. If your potatoes are larger than normal (e.g. you are using a russet potato rather than a small white or red potato), you may need to cut them into more than 4 quarters. Ideally, your cubed potatoes will be about 1 inch (2.5 cm) square each.

steps.headline: Mince the garlic cloves and set them aside.
steps.description: Peel the skin off from the garlic, and use a knife to trim off the root end. Put the garlic onto the cutting board, and use your knife to cut off thin slices. Chop the garlic slices into smaller bits. If you don’t have fresh garlic, you can use store-bought pre-minced garlic, or substitute ⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) of garlic powder for each clove of garlic you need.

steps.headline: Place the potatoes into a large mixing bowl.
steps.description: Choose a bowl that can contain the potatoes without them reaching or extending over the edge. You can use a glass or a plastic bowl, just make sure it is clean before you put the potatoes into it. If you don’t have a mixing bowl, you could instead use a gallon-size ziplock bag.

steps.headline: Toss the potatoes with the olive oil, pepper, and chopped garlic.
steps.description: Use ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of olive oil, 1 and ⁄2 teaspoon (4.9 and 2.5 mL) of ground black pepper, and 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of minced garlic. Shake the bowl and gently toss the potatoes up and down to coat them evenly. Or, use a large spoon to toss the potatoes several times. If you are using a ziplock bag, simply add the olive oil, pepper, and garlic to the bag with the potatoes, zip it shut, and shake it vigorously until all the potatoes are coated evenly.

steps.headline: Spread the potatoes out evenly on a baking sheet.
steps.description: Use a sheet that is large enough to hold all the potatoes without having to stack them on top of each other. Leave a little space in-between the potatoes where you can, as that will help the hot air cook the potatoes more evenly. For easy cleanup, line the baking sheet with aluminum foil before adding the potatoes.

steps.headline: Bake the potatoes for 45 minutes to 1 hour, flipping twice.
steps.description: Every 20 minutes, use oven mitts to take the potatoes out of the oven and flip them over using a spatula. This helps them cook more evenly. The potatoes are finished when they are pierced easily with a fork. Remember to use your oven mitts even when you are flipping the potatoes, as the baking sheet will be very hot!

steps.headline: Remove the potatoes from the oven and sprinkle them with parsley.
steps.description: Use 2 teaspoons (9.9 mL) of freshly chopped parsley to give your potatoes a fresh element to complement the garlic flavor. If you don’t have fresh parsley, use 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of dried parsley for every 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of fresh parsley your recipe calls for.

steps.headline: Refrigerate the leftovers for 3-5 days.
steps.description: If you aren’t eating all of the potatoes immediately after cooking, try to get them into the fridge within 2 hours. Use an air-tight container to store the potatoes. If they are left on the counter for longer than that, or overnight, you should discard them to be safe. Label the container with the date you made the potatoes so you will remember when you need to use them by.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 425 °F (218 °C) and cube 2 large potatoes.
steps.description: You can use either sweet potatoes or white potatoes for this recipe. Use a clean cutting board and a sharp kitchen knife, and slice the potatoes lengthwise, then cut them into equal-sized cubes. If the potatoes have any spuds growing out of them, just pick them off with your fingers and throw them away. You can also peel the potatoes if you want, but you don’t have to.

steps.headline: Drizzle the potatoes with 3 US tbsp (44 mL) of with olive oil.
steps.description: Put the potatoes into a mixing bowl that is large enough that you can shake them around without having them fall out of the container. If you don’t have olive oil, you could also use the same amounts of avocado oil, grape seed oil, or coconut oil.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the dry spices and sugar over the potatoes.
steps.description: Use 2 teaspoons (9.9 mL) of brown sugar, 1 and ⁄2 tablespoon (14.8 and 7.4 mL) of paprika, ⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) of ground black pepper, ⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) of onion powder, ⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) of garlic powder, and ⁄2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) of chili powder. If you like your food a little spicier, add more paprika and chili powder. Likewise, if you would prefer a slightly sweeter dish, add a little more brown sugar.

steps.headline: Toss the potatoes in the mixing bowl until they’re evenly coated.
steps.description: Either shake the potatoes around in the bowl, or use a large spoon to toss them several times, making sure that they are all coated evenly with the oil and seasonings. If you don’t want to use a mixing bowl, you can also place the potatoes and other ingredients into a large ziplock bag and shake them up that way.

steps.headline: Spread the potatoes evenly on a baking sheet.
steps.description: Use a large sheet that leaves enough space to hold all of the potatoes without having to stack them on top of one another. Leave a little space in-between the potatoes where you can, as that will help the hot air cook the potatoes more evenly. For easy cleanup, cover the baking sheet with a layer of aluminum foil before spreading out the potatoes.

steps.headline: Bake the potatoes for 25 minutes, flipping them once.
steps.description: After the first 15 minutes, use oven mitts to take the tray out of the oven, then use a spatula to flip the potatoes over. Cook them for an additional 10 minutes, or until the potatoes are easily pierced with a fork. The smaller the cubes of potato, the faster they will cook. If you have really small cubes, make sure to check them frequently to ensure they aren’t burning.

steps.headline: Remove the potatoes from the oven and let them cool for 4-5 minutes.
steps.description: Turn the oven off and let the baking tray sit on top of the stove for a few minutes before transferring the potatoes to a serving dish or plates. When you transfer the potatoes, use an oven mitt in case the baking sheet is still hot. You could even drizzle a little honey overtop of the potatoes for an extra sweet element.

steps.headline: Refrigerate the leftovers for 3-5 days.
steps.description: Either eat the potatoes or move them into the fridge within 2 hours of cooking them, otherwise they can grow certain harmful bacterias. Use an airtight container when you store them in the fridge. If you leave them on the counter overnight, dispose of them rather than trying to reheat or refrigerate them. Label the container with the “cooked on” date, so you will remember how long your leftovers will be good for.
